div.p: Hence minimizing over each D KL (π i,i+1 | (p A,H ) i,i+1 ) (for π ∈ Π(p i , p i+1 )) is equivalent to minimizing over Markovian π's with ith marginal p i .

The previous proposition assumes that D KL (p i | Leb) < ∞ for all i ̸ = 0. The following brief computation shows that this assumption is satisfied in the case where the diffusion matrix is non-degenerate.

We note that X t ∼ e At X 0 + t 0 e A(t-s) GdW s . As X 0 is independent from the Brownian noise W s , and t 0 e A(t-s) GdW s ∼ N (0, Σ t ), where Σ t = t 0 e A(t-s) He A ⊤ (t-s) ds, it follows that p t = p 0 * N (0, Σ t ).
Thus, we may compute [Cov99, Theorem 9.4.1] D KL (N (0, Σ t ) | Leb) = 1 2 log(2πe) d det(Σ t ).

From the definition of Σ t , we note that det(Σ t ) ̸ = 0 as long as H = GG ⊤ is full rank. Then, we use the fact that the D KL (• | Leb) is convex, and apply Jensen's inequality for measures, to deduce that This shows directly that p t has finite entropy whenever t > 0 as desired.
div.formula: D
div.p: Remark 7.16 (Applying EOT for SDE trajectory inference). In the standard ϵ-regularized OT problem (22), the cost is the squared Euclidean distance, and K ∼ N (x, ϵ 2 I d ) is an isotropic Gaussian kernel. As noted in [LZKS21], this implies that entropy regularized OT can be leveraged for trajectory inference from observed marginals, given a reference SDE. For example, to find the discretized law on paths π * ∈ Π(µ, ν) satisfying P (X t = µ, X t+∆t = ν), which minimizes relative entropy to the law of a pure diffusion process dX t = σdW t , one should set the entropic regularization ϵ 2 = σ 2 ∆t. This would correspond to minimizing the KL divergence to K(x, y) = e -∥y-x∥ 2 2σ 2 ∆t ∼ N (x, σ 2 ∆t), which is the transition kernel of the reference SDE. Similarly, as done in [Zha24], one can perform trajectory inference given an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck reference SDE dX t = -AX t dt+σdW t by approximating the transition distribution X t+∆t|t via K(x, y) = e -∥y-e A∆t x∥ 2 2σ 2 ∆t . This would correspond to reweighting the squared Euclidean cost with the drift matrix A, such that c(x, y) = ∥y -e A∆t x∥/2, and applying standard entropy regularized OT with ϵ 2 = σ 2 ∆t.

div.head: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
div.p: Proof of Proposition (4.2). We follow the standard procedure [PMA03,Pav14] for deriving maximum likelihood estimators. Our likelihood function is given by

(b) This corresponds to Example 7.2, with X0 ∼ Unif{(2, 0), (2, 0.1)}. The first SDE is irrotational and maintains mean (2, 0.05). The second SDE (right) rotates about the origin. div.head: Weak formulation of the Fokker-Planck equation
div.p: We may define the linear operator L
L is the generator of the additive noise SDE (2) [HC15]. Its adjoint operator is given by (L * g)(x) = -∇ • (b(x, t)g(x)) + ∇ • (H∇g(x)).
and satisfies

for all smooth and compactly supported test functions f, g ∈ C ∞ c (R d ). Then, the Fokker-Planck equation can be formulated in the weak sense as follows. For each t ≥ 0 let p t be a probability measure on R d and assume that t → p t is narrowly continuous. Then we say p t solves the Fokker-Planck equation in the weak sense provided that

This weak formulation accommodates the case where b is not differentiable and p t is not necessarily absolutely continuous with respect to the Lebesgue measure. For p t with sufficiently regular Lebesgue density p(x, t) this weak solution concept is equivalent to the classical sense of the Fokker-Planck equation, i.e.

For the measure-theoretic weak formulation of the Fokker-Planck equation, we quote the following existence and uniqueness results from [Str08]. Under our standing assumptions on the drift and diffusion coefficients (namely: the drift is linear, and the diffusion is constant but possibly degenerate), by [Str08] Theorem 1.1.9 weak solutions to the Fokker-Planck equation exist whenever the initial condition ρ 0 has finite second moments; and moreover, by Theorem 2.2.9 in [Str08], the solution is unique provided that all moments of ρ 0 are finite.

div.head: Properties of auto-rotationally invariant r.v.s
div.p: Lemma 7.4. Let Σ ≻ 0 and A ∈ R d×d be such that
Then, B = Σ 1/2 A Σ -1/2 is skew-symmetric, and for all t ∈ R,

In other words, the Σ-generalized rotation e At produces a classical rotation e Bt after the change of variables y = Σ 1/2 x, which can be interpreted as a shearing and scaling transformation of R d .
Proof. Since Σ ≻ 0, the unique symmetric positive definite square root Σ 1/2 exists and is invertible. Define
Then, since AΣ + ΣA T = 0, we can multiply on the left by Σ -1/2 and on the right by Σ -1/2 to yield
which proves that B is skew-symmetric, and therefore e Bt defines a classical rotation in R d , such that
where the last equality can be seen by writing e Bt = ∞ n=0 t n B n n! and noting that B n = (Σ -1/2 AΣ 1/2 ) n = Σ -1/2 A n Σ 1/2 . Rearranging yields e At = Σ -1/2 e Bt Σ 1/2 as desired.
To explicitly see that the change of variable y = Σ 1/2 x amounts to a shearing and scaling, note that any positive definite matrix admits an LDL T factorization:

where L is unit lower-triangular (so its off-diagonal entries describe a shear transformation) and D is a diagonal matrix with positive entries (representing scaling along the coordinate axes). Thus, the transformation x → y = Σ 1/2 x decomposes into a shear (via L) and a scaling (via D 1/2 ). Lemma 7.5. Let X be a r.v. with covariance Σ and suppose that e At X ∼ X. Then, AΣ + ΣA T = 0.
Proof. Let C(t) = Cov(e At X). e At X ∼ X implies that for all t ≥ 0, C(t) = Cov(X) = Σ. Hence,
Lemma 7.6. Let Cov(X) = Σ ≻ 0 and suppose that e At X ∼ X for some A ̸ = 0. Then X admits a density, and the level sets of its probability density function are Σ-rotationally invariant ellipsoids:
Σ , the probability distribution of X must be constant within each ellipsoid
thus inducing a probability density function on X.
Lemma 7.7. Let X be a d dimensional r.v. such that dim(span(X)) < d with probability 1. Then, e At X ∼ X admits a non-trivial solution A ̸ = 0.
Proof. We expand
Hence, a sufficient condition for the claim is that X is in the nullspace of A with probability 1. Since dim(span(X)) < d a.s., then by the rank-nullity theorem, there exists A such that AX = 0 a.s.
Proposition 7.8. Let X 0 ∼ p 0 be a discrete random variable. Then X 0 is not auto-rotationally invariant if and only if the support of p 0 spans R d .

Proof. Lemma 7.7 provides the only if direction. Now, let span(X 0 ) = R d a.s. Since e At represents a continuous transformation, and X 0 is supported on a discrete set of points, which cannot all be mapped to 0 by A, it follows that the support would shift for each t > 0. We conclude that e At X 0 ̸ ∼ X 0 .
